title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
author: Aesop

content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a small, contented mouse named Timothy. Timothy was a country mouse, and he loved his simple life.
His home was a cozy burrow beneath the roots of an old oak tree, where the earth was warm and the air smelled of fresh hay and wildflowers.
Every morning, he would wake with the sun, stretch his tiny paws, and scamper out to gather seeds, berries, and the sweetest grains from the fields.
He had all he needed—plenty to eat, a safe place to sleep, and the gentle rustling of leaves to sing him to sleep each night.

One bright summer day, as Timothy was nibbling on a ripe blackberry, he heard a rustling in the tall grass. Out popped his old friend, Oliver, a town mouse who had come to visit from the bustling city far
away. Oliver was dressed in a smart little waistcoat and carried a tiny suitcase, as if he were on a grand adventure. "Timothy!" Oliver squeaked, his whiskers twitching with excitement.
"How wonderful to see you! I’ve missed our chats under the stars." Timothy beamed and offered his friend the juiciest berry. "Oliver! What brings you all the way to the countryside?
It’s been ages!" Oliver sighed dramatically and sat down on a smooth pebble. "Oh, Timothy, you wouldn’t believe the life I’ve been living!
The city is *marvelous*—full of lights, music, and the most delicious food you could ever imagine. Why, just last week, I feasted on crumbs of the finest cheese, bits of chocolate, and even a drop of

honey from a baker’s shop! You simply *must* come and visit me. I’ll show you the grandest time!" Timothy tilted his head, his nose twitching thoughtfully. "It sounds exciting, Oliver, but I’m not sure.
The city is so far away, and I’ve heard it’s noisy and crowded. Here, I have peace and quiet, and everything I need." Oliver waved a paw dismissively. "Peace and quiet?
My dear friend, you don’t know what you’re missing! The city is alive with adventure. Come, just for a little while. I promise you’ll love it!"
Timothy hesitated, but the sparkle in Oliver’s eyes was hard to resist. "Well… all right. But only for a short visit. I do love my home here." Oliver clapped his paws together. "Wonderful!
We’ll leave at once. The city awaits!" And so, the two mice set off on their journey. Timothy had never traveled far from his oak tree, and the sights along the way filled him with wonder.
They passed through golden wheat fields, crossed babbling brooks, and even sneaked a peek at a sleepy old barn where cows dozed in the shade.
But as they drew closer to the city, the air grew thicker, the sounds louder, and the smells—oh, the smells were strange and strong.

Timothy’s whiskers trembled a little, but he told himself it was all part of the adventure. At last, they arrived at Oliver’s home—a snug little hole in the wall of a grand house, hidden behind a loose
brick. The moment they stepped inside, Timothy’s eyes widened. The room was filled with the most incredible treasures: crumbs of cake, bits of fruit, even a half-eaten biscuit!
Oliver grinned proudly. "See? Isn’t it magnificent?" Timothy had to admit, it was impressive. "This is… quite something, Oliver. But where does all this food come from?"
Oliver puffed out his chest. "From the humans, of course! They leave scraps everywhere—under the table, by the pantry, even in the trash bins. It’s like a never-ending feast!"
Just then, the sound of heavy footsteps echoed through the house. A door creaked open, and a deep voice boomed, "Who’s there? I hear something!" Oliver’s ears flattened against his head.
"Quick, Timothy! Hide!" The two mice darted behind a crack in the wall just as a large human stomped into the room.
The human grumbled, "Must be those pesky mice again," and began searching the floor with a broom. Timothy’s heart pounded so loudly he was sure the human could hear it.
The broom swept dangerously close to their hiding spot, and Timothy squeezed his eyes shut, trembling. Oliver, however, seemed used to this. He whispered, "Don’t worry. They never find us.
Just stay still." After what felt like an eternity, the human sighed and left the room, muttering about setting traps. The moment the coast was clear, Oliver let out a nervous laugh. "See?
Nothing to worry about! Now, where were we? Ah, yes—the feast!" But Timothy’s appetite was gone. His tiny paws still shook, and his stomach twisted with fear.
"Oliver… I don’t think I can stay here. It’s too scary. The humans, the noise, the constant danger—it’s not for me." Oliver’s ears drooped. "But Timothy, you haven’t even seen the best parts!
The theaters, the markets, the—" Timothy shook his head gently. "I appreciate the invitation, truly I do. But my home is where I belong.
There, I can eat my berries in peace, listen to the birds sing, and sleep without fear. I think… I think I’d like to go back now." Oliver sighed, but he nodded understandingly.
"I suppose I can’t blame you. The city isn’t for everyone. But promise me you’ll visit again someday?" Timothy smiled. "Of course. And you must come back to the countryside too.
I’ll save you the sweetest blackberries!" With that, the two friends said their goodbyes, and Timothy began the long journey home.
As he scampered through the fields, the familiar sights and sounds wrapped around him like a warm blanket. The sun dipped below the hills, painting the sky in shades of pink and gold, and the

crickets began their evening song. By the time he reached his oak tree, he knew he had made the right choice. That night, as he curled up in his cozy burrow, Timothy whispered to the quiet darkness, "There’s
no place like home." And with a contented sigh, he drifted off to sleep, dreaming of berries, sunshine, and the gentle rustle of leaves.
